history.content:
Machine learning taught well will probably be theoretical -- otherwise you'd be taking a semester on scikit/tensorflow/whatever new library there is now. I think that since the field evolves so rapidly, a toolkit-based education might not be nearly as valuable decades from now.

As far as 164 goes, I'd argue that you should know how a language makes its way down, and is highly rewarding when combined with 151/152 (I got to work on this stuff at an internship last summer and it was great). Between EECS 152, CS164, CS162, you should be able to design a processor, and get an operating system up and running.

From the "usefulness" perspective, it highly depends on what type of CS you want to go into. CS189 by itself likely won't prepare you adequately for machine learning, while compilers/arch usually leads into very specialized roles.

I don't know which one is more useful to finding a CS related job, can someone provide insight for me? 

I know machine learning is popular, but i find people say 189 is more theoretical than practical, so I am not sure.

For the difficulty level, is 164 tougher than 189? I know 164 is about programming language and compiler, but I don't know if it is more useful than 189. 

And I have read the HKN class map, so they are both heavy work oriented. 

Thanks for any help!
history.subject: help on class decision:189 or 164?
